overview_of_class:
? This course will examine the fundamental molecular processes that govern the fate and transformation of organic contaminants in natural environmental systems and engineered treatment processes.

? Thermodynamic principles and molecular property descriptors are used throughout the course to develop predictive relationships for organic contaminant solubility and partitioning between environmental phases (e.g., water, air, biota), sorption to solid surfaces (e.g., soils, sediments, aerosol particles), and transformation processes (e.g., oxidation, reduction, hydrolysis, photolysis, biological).
name: Environmental Organic Chemistry
title: MEAS CIV_ENV 370-0-20 Environmental Organic Chemistry
enrl_requirement: Enrollment Requirements: Prerequisite: Student must have received a C- or higher or be currently enrolled in CHEM 210-1, or be a graduate student to register for this course.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
? This course will examine the fundamental molecular processes that govern the fate and transformation of organic contaminants in natural environmental systems and engineered treatment processes.

? Thermodynamic principles and molecular property descriptors are used throughout the course to develop predictive relationships for organic contaminant solubility and partitioning between environmental phases (e.g., water, air, biota), sorption to solid surfaces (e.g., soils, sediments, aerosol particles), and transformation processes (e.g., oxidation, reduction, hydrolysis, photolysis, biological).

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Should have taken introductory course in organic chemistry (or working knowledge of organic chemistry nomenclature)
Course in aquatic chemistry or physical chemistry recommended

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Environmental Organic Chemistry, 2nd Edition, by Schwarzenbach, Gschwend and Imboden.

subject: CIV_ENV
